This is a extension for Flone (open source quadcopter) to draw/paint with spray paint.
Hope it would be a great useful tool for writer's new expression in this era. Test flight & drawing
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jKREAeBDiTk About Flone:
http://flone.aeracoop.net/ How to make a Flone:
http://flone.aeracoop.net/doc/wiki/
http://www.instructables.com/id/Flone/
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:113497/#instructions Flone is developed by Lot (http://feenelcaos.org/).
This extension is developed in Hangar.org (http://hangar.org) Barcelona, Spain with Lot.

Parts needed:
  • Spray Paint (Montana Water Based 100 http://goo.gl/d4zVrh) x1
  • Needle Cap x1
  • Fat Cap x1
  • Silicone Tube (2ø x 180mm) x1
  • Servo (23x11x29mm) x1
  • Zip Tie x2
  • Nut (3ø) x3
  • Bolt (3ø x over 8mm) x2
  • Bolt (3ø x over 28mm) x1
  • Clip x1
  • Printed Parts (servo_mounter_base_w_support.stl, servo_mounter_trigg.stl, nozzle_mounter.stl)
    • Instructions:
  • Remove support material from printed parts.
  • Connect silicone tube and caps.
  • Cut the clip and bend it proper shape to attach the trigger.
  • Mount the servo on the base with zip ties.
  • Assemble them like image above.
  • Servo cable should be connected to flight controller board.
    • Note:
  • "nozzle_mounter.stl" is only fits for Montana Water Base 100.
  • Servo Mounter Base can fits all size of Montana cans.

description.text: I added Revars LCD mod http://wiki.makerbot.com/revarlcd-assembly to my cupcake and love it. After serching for a way to enclose my LCD and Keypad, I decided to make my own. So this is what I came up with. I hope others can use it as well. I highly recommend adding this mod to all makerbots. Not only does it allow you to print without a computer hooked up to your bot but it will only cost you about $70.00 to build.

Print both halves of the LCD case and use CA glue to bond them together. Next screw the LCD into the case. You can buy CA glue at any hobby store for about $5.00. CA glue kind of melts the pieces together and is just as strong as the ABS itself. The keypad is only one print and fits very well. Screw it into the case. Now mount the cases to the front of your Makerbot. I used a couple of screws and and ran them from the inside of the bot into the rim of the case.

comments.author: jag

comments.text: I looked at the schematics for the Gen4 motherboard, and there IS one possible way to make this work, but it'll take some firmware recoding.  The I2C pins are being (mis)used for SD card detect and SD lock detect, but the Gen4 MB has 4 Serial UARTS of which only two are being used.  The Modtronix can be used via I2C, SPI, or Serial, so if the firmware is changed to use Serial to talk to the LCD instead of I2C, then it should be possible to get this working.  Unfortunately the TXD/RXD pins for those two spare UARTS are being used for the Z and A axis stepper controllers.  If you mod the 5D code to use the B stepper instead of the A stepper, then you should be able to break out the TXD/RXD for the UART on the A axis jack, and get the serial lines you need for the LCD.  That said, I do not have a Gen4 MB to test with, and can't really afford one at the moment.

title: CRASH Space loves you LED heart-light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The CRASH Space loves you LED heart light was originally developed as a Valentine's Day promotion at Cinefamily's Electric Dreams Pajama Party. It is now being used as a thank you gift for donations and general swag.
We are providing this file for other hackerspaces to use in the same way and for individuals to share the love.

This project is incredibly simple. Print it out, pop in the components, assemble the pieces. The biggest potential mistakes are putting the heart on backwards or reversing the leads of the LED. To keep the LED leads in place I used a Rubber band made from a bicycle inner tube. We've also used conductive tape, regular tape and regular rubber bands You can see the set on flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/crashspacela/sets/72157625937579403/ Special thanks go to Tod Kurt, Carlyn Maw, Steven Goldstein and Matt Pinner

Designed and printed this as a direct replacement for the useless cup holders in my '98 Subaru Legacy Outback. Yeah, it blocks the climate controls, but so did anything placed in the cup holders and my phone won't drip and fry my stereo. I designed this specifically for my Note 3 with a TPU case installed. Should work with somewhat thicker cases and other phablets. If anyone else happens to have a Subaru of this vintage and would like one of these specifically designed for their phone just shoot me a message. I'll mod the design and add it to the file list. 2/1/2015 - Added design mod for Nexus 5 per user request. Nexus 5 model source https://grabcad.com/library/lg-nexus-5-1/files/NEXUS%205.STEP 3/17/2015 - Added design mod for iPhone 5 per user request. Designed with thin case in mind ~3mm extra space added around the interior of the phone pocket. iPhone 5 model source https://grabcad.com/library/iphone-5-precise-detailed-model-for-case-designers/files/iphone5_tsd.stp

Designed with SolidWorks.  Printed on my XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 using their firmware and slicing app.  Settings: 0.2mm layer height, 30% fill, no supports, no raft.  This is a large piece (~198.5mm) so I rotated it 45 degrees on the Z axis to ensure a good print.  Position it flat on the print surface like you were going to put your phone in it.  
2/1/2015 - Same instructions should apply for Nexus 5 holder.  
3/17/2015 - Same instructions should apply for iPhone 5 holder.

description.text:
My second Pinewood Derby car.
Basically is a sketchup model that I modified to work within the parameters of that little block of wood. I went ahead and created this one as an 1/8" shell that goes over a companion pinewood car.

SketchUp is a must if you want to build this...it has the info for the cuts for the pinewood portion of this build.
I printed this with PLA, Full support and raft.  Not sure that it matters about the fill, but I think I had it set at 15 or 25%.
I am supplying the sketchup file, an stl and a repaired stl repaired in netfab.

author: EvilBadger

description.text: Dome light lense cover for a Datsun model 620 Pick Up. This will replace the dome lense in your 1976 Datsun pick up. It will fit other years, check your vehicle to be sure.

Move this object to the center. I printed several different ways and the best approach is use Rafts and Supports, standard resolution setting, open side down. The rafts will easily break away and give you a clean part. You can polish the flat surface after, but the pictures are untouched. The finish is very good as is. I printed in PLA natural.
Here's another trick; the housing this will snap on may have worn tabs. They were made of white plastic and by now they can be very brittle. The standard file here will slip on a perfect housing. If it's too loose, try rescaling by adjusting the Y axis from 42mm to 41mm. Let the X and Z change uniform. There's enough room for the part to work perfectly while you tighten up the fit on your housing. Don't force it on the housing! They are very brittle at this age. Scale the Y up or down a millimeter at a time to get the best fit. Questions and other parts to model are welcome.

title: OpenSCAD - faster coding with ShortCuts library and new primitives

description.text:
[be sure to always have downloaded the latest version!] OpenSCAD is a wonderful means to forget about time. I love programming with it and am almost adicted to do design in the mathematical way.
But, also being well acquainted to some more professional IDEs like Eclipse and VisualStudio, I must admit that one day I got really tired about having to type always the same stuff like difference(){
rotate([0, 0, 45]) translate([0, 0, 4])
cylinder(r = 100, h = 10, center = true]);
rotate([0, 0, -45]) translate([0, 0, 4])
cylinder(r = 100, h = 10, center = true]);
} My solution was to write a private shortcut library which speeded up my coding drastically. And it is so much fun to write libraries, because one gets into contact with the more advanced language features. In this little project I am presenting you my 'best of' library. A collection of my most used shortcuts and extended primitives for MUCH faster programming. The most important shortcuts are the transformations and logical operations:
To enhance translate([x, y, z]) I defined T(x = 0, y=0, z=0)
Tx(x=0)
Ty(y = 0)
Tz(z =0) Similar abbreviations exist for rotate() and scale(). Logical operators difference() and union() are aliased by D() and U(). If you miss intersection(): I couldn't make it work. If you find a solution, please let me know. Primitives also have aliases cylinder() -> Cy()
cube() -> Cu()
circle() -> Ci()
square() -> Sq()
sphere() -> Sp() with usable defaults, like being CENTERED. Using primitives not being centered by default is so time consuming. Additionally I put some extended primitives into this library that are for daily use, like ring() -> Ri()
ring_half() -> RiH()
ring_segment() -> RiS()
cylinder_half() -> CyH()
cylinder_segment() -> CyS() or Pie()
circle_half() -> CiH()
circle_segment() -> CiS()
sphere_half() -> SpH() To know what's in the lib you get a 'cheat sheet' in the console from help() To make the lib available for your code, copy ShortCut.scad into your OpenSCAD libaries folder or current project folder and reference it with include in your code. I use this library for fast, sloppy and sketchy programming and it saves me lots and lots of time. Of course when it gets more and more into reusable programming, these shortcuts might be to cryptic. Also for publishing code. This might be a draw back, but it forces one to rethink the code and make it even better, when transcoding it back to the commonly readable format. By the way, did you miss SpS() ? I hardly ever use it. But if you do, please, let me know your implementation. Anyway, have fun with enlarging the lib.

comments.text: This should be on Github. Please let me know if I can assist with this process.  Happy to help.

title: A.M.V.P Mk.III (Chinchilla) 6x6 AFV
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a 1/72 scale model of a fictional AFV. The print area is 14x10cm or about 5 1/2"x4", so it should fit in most desktop printers. I kept the overall surface detail light as well as recessed to allow for easy printing and finishing. The model clips together, no glue required; however, the wheels could benefit from a little adhesive for extra security. The clips holding the hull sections together and the clips securing the turret fit quite tightly; some filing may be needed. The moving parts, axles, and turret may need to be filed or sanded to move more freely. Traditional model kit parts can be added to increase the level of detail, but even the basic print makes a great little model/toy. Not suitable for children under 3.

When printing this model I used a raft and supports. The top half of the hull will require it. The axles and gun will benefit from a raft.
Place the turret cylinder through the circular hole in the upper hull section.
Attach the turret to the turret cylinder, using clips to secure.
Select either the gun or the gun mount provided in the print; secure your selected mount to the turret using the clipping mechanism.
Secure the upper hull section to the lower hull section by pressing together tightly to clip.
Place axles through provided holes on the lower hull section, place a tire on each end of the three axles. (Some glue may be required to ensure a secure fit)

description.text:
This is my attempt to secure my ferrets' litter pan to their cage. I bought a litter pan that already does this but it's only secured at the top and they can easily move the pan and have even managed to break a piece of the bolt mechanism.  
I will use this to add more points to lock the pan in place. Once I've printed it out and worked out the kinks I'll upload a photo.

Use a drill to make one or more holes in the desired place(s) in your litter pan. Insert the bolt so that the head of the bolt is inside the litter pan. Secure the nut so the bolt is snuggly attached to the littler pan. Once the litter pan is back in the cage slide the washer over the bolt from the outside of the cage and then attach the wing nut to secure the litter pan to the cage. title: Toyota 4 Cylinder Engine 22RE, Complete working model

description.text:
All my models are printed on a Prusa i3 kit. You can find the one I use by clicking the link below. You can get 15% off by using code "GBTE"
Tronxy Prusa I3 Completely reverse engineered Toyota 22RE 4 cylinder engine. Can completely print a fully rotating model. Working crank, pistons, and valve train. The valves open and close!!!. It may not be the most exciting engine but its the only one I had in my garage. Great if you want to learn about engines and how the moving parts in them work. All parts are printed except for a few bearings and fasteners.
More than 3 days of total print time.
The block alone was 34 hours. So make sure you have a well calibrated and reliable printer. Some print times calculated in Cura at .2mm layer height
Engine Block - 40 hours
Head - 23 hours
Valve Cover - 10 hours
Oil pan - 14 hours http://youtu.be/mmK_LWOqRp8

Update 05/29/2017: Please look at the remixes of this thing. There you will find other parts and improvements that I and others have made. Like a stronger drive motor that drive the flywheel directly instead of using a belt. I have also updated the cylinder head to have the valve on the proper side. Update 02/01/2015: Updated the oil pan, timing cover, and rear main cover to use 4mm x 2mm disc magnets so that the oil pan will stay on better. Glue magnets in and allow each magnet to be exposed roughly 1mm above surface to allow a gap between the block and the oil pan. Note!!! Connecting rod caps and spacer .125 were not scaled properly. Way too big/small. Updated 01/27/2015 Update 01/27/2015: Added ported version of head. Has 3mm holes for spark plugs or LEDs for future upgrades. Print with support touching build plate. printed nicely, just a good amount of support material to remove and clean up. But you can see the valve moving if you look through the ports. Update 01/27/2015: Made intake manifold. Lower can be printed without any support. Upper as been split into two halfs to print and then glue together later. I also uploaded the whole upper intake if you want to print it with all support. Manifold attaches with 4mmx2mm magnets just like the header. I used 14 magnets total(7 on each side. 5 on top, 2 on bottom) due to the weight of the intake. I assembled the lower, upper, and throttle bossy with m3 SHCS but you can glue it if you want. Will upload a new version of the head that is ported with spark plug holes tomorrow. Just test printing it now. Update 01/25/2015: I made a header for the engine and uploaded it. It printed wonderfully in Cura with support. Make sure to select "touching buildplate" for you support option as the header is hollow just like a real one and if you don't, it will fill the inside with support. It's held on with 8 4mm x 2mm disk earth magnets epoxied in. This model was reverse engineered from a 22RE Toyota engine, All modeling was done in SolidWorks and the STL files were scaled to 35% for printing since that the biggest my printer could print. All parts were printed in PLA on my RepRap original Prusa. There are 80 printed parts in this assembly, not including any fasteners or bearings. Probably a whole 1kg roll of plastic.
The model can be built in different stages, if you only want the short block then only print those parts. The head is completely removable so you can see the pistons moving and also the valves opening and closing. The oil pan is attached with magnets so you can take it off and see the crankshaft moving.
It's a complex print and model. Total print time of the block at 35% scale of the original was just over 34 hours. Just the head print time was 20 hours. Make sure you have a well calibrated and robust machine if you want to print this. It's definitely is a challenge for you and your printer. You can scale the model even further but sourcing bearings and fasteners will be an issue.
See the hardware list for all none printed parts, bearings are all common bearings used on 3D printers so they should be easy to source. Hardware is best sourced from bolt depot since you can purchase individual quantities. For the valve springs, I formed them using my drill and a 1/4" ratchet extension as a mandrel. I used 0.023" steel mig welding wire but you can use anything similar. The outer diameter of the spring should roughly be 0.470". Each spring has 10 loops and just stretch it long enough to keep the valve closed. I wasn't able to find a pre-made springs with the right size and spring constant. If somebody does know of a spring that will work with this please let me know.
For Drive belts to connect the fan pulley and the electric motor, I used rubber bands. The crank pulley and electric motor pulley are setup to use a timing belt but I never got around to sourcing one. The teeth spacing is for a gates extra light timing belt. 1/8" wide, and .080" pitch.
If you do decide to print and build this model you will probably run into some fitment issues due to different printers, plastics, etc. If you have any questions let me know. All STL files are good, they have been repaired with NetFabb so there shouldn't be any problems there. I'll upload assembly drawings in the future when I get a chance.

comments.text:
Valves ease made
The Valves (and the spring retainers) I made with metal shims and a brass rods 2.9mm (common in the shops). On the left side on the picture the exhaust, on the right the intake valve, in the center the standoff for centering and aligning the shims and stem.
8 pieces shim inner 3.2mm, outer diameter 13mm exhaust and intake valves
4 pieces inner 6.4mm, outer diameter 16mm for intake valves (all common in shops)
Cut 6cm long full-brass pieces as valve stem and make to one side a threat M3, approx. 4mm long.
Take a piece of hardwood as building jig approx 15/20mm thickness.
Make a bushing, the diameter is corresponding with inner hole dim. of the 16mm shim.
Into this bushing (ca. 15mm long for a good alignment in the wood) cut in the center an internal threat M3.
Drill a hole into the hardwood and put this bushing with a little got over, to fit the 16mm shim in center hole.
Now you can built the valves by gluing with epoxy, or soldering
screw in the valve brass, put the 16mm shim over the bushing, glue/solder the smaller shim into place and fill with glue/solder for a fluiding-transition to the stem. Build also the smaller valves with the jig, but first make flush the bushing with the surface of the jig.

comments.text: The holes on the Intake, header, and head are larger to accommodate 4x2mm disc magnets.  I used 8 for the header, 4 for each mating face.  And I used 14 for the intake, 7 on each face.  This allows you to easily remove both and see inside the ports if you printed the ported version. The magnets we epoxied into both faces at the same time to produce an even mating surface for the magnets, separating them with painters tape,

comments.text: Just finished the bottom half.  I think you should consider adding more locations for magnets.  Atleast 8 minimum on the bottom if using such small magnets.  I would go 10.  I have not done the top end yet but gravity is helping out on top.
comments.author: andyman2000

comments.text: What magnets are you using? I stacked two magnets at  each location on the oil pan so that any differences in the block and oil pan would be compensated for and also left a gap between the two. I also glued the magnets in the block last and installed the oil pan before the glue cured so that all the magnets were aligned.  Does you oil pan just fall off or bump off easily?
comments.author: andyman2000

comments.text: Now, I remember. i double stacked the magnets to clear the main bearing cap bolts.  They stick out too far and hit the oil pan.  I'll enlarge the holes in the block and oil pan to use 4mm x 2mm disk magnets. That way all the magnets will be the same for the block.
comments.author: ericthepoolboy

comments.text: that makes sense.  I didn't want the gap so I pulled the old dremel out and I notched out some material for the bolts.  I wasn't aware I had to double up on the magnets so I just added a few more.  I guess since there is a slight gap to the magnets, that would explain why mine don't hold as well.

comments.text: just printed the timing gears for the valve train.  Lots of friction there.  Also same the piston assembly thru the piston chambers.  Lots of sanding there.  But the valve train is the hardest.  If the gears are not perfectly aligned and the holes are slightly off center, lots of friction.
comments.author: andyman2000

comments.text: The clearance between the pistons and cylinder wall was set to be pretty tight. The idea was that  you could sand the wall and the piston so that it would be smooth with no layers showing so that there would be less friction or binding. You can always scale down the pistons slightly if there is still too mush material to be removed. As for the timing gears, I havent experienced much friction at all. I updated the assembly drawing to show that there are 2 jam nuts behind the bearing to help keep the gears from moving side to side.  Also, I hit every gear tooth with a tiny flat file to help smooth things out. But you can also scale the gears down too if you want.
comments.author: andyman2000

comments.text: No need to scale anything down.  Just wanted to let people know what to expect.  I've got the bottom end done.  I noticed that the cap screw heads for the conn rod ends are rubbing against the block.  So I had to pull the old dremel out and take some material off the block where the cap rubs.   I also had to take sand down and file the timing gears to ensure smoothness.  Same thing with the piston and walls.  Sanded those down too to open up the tolerance.  The tolerances are pretty tight which I like, but my makerbot 2x isn't producing products that are as tight on tolerance.  Now that the bottom half is done, I have to sell well done!  I love it.  I'm printing the ported head now.  Look forward to it!
comments.author: ericthepoolboy

comments.text: Friction was the biggest issue when designing this. I did encounter the connecting rod screws hitting the block and removed some material from the block and the connecting rods, but I guess not enough.  How much material did you have to remove?
comments.author: andyman2000

comments.text: I think the biggest problem is the SHCS.  Its just too big.  I think if we used hex bolts instead it would be better.  Also if I were forced to use SHCS maybe it should be counter sinked?  Not sure if theres enough material.  I think changing to hex screws would be best.   As for material I had to remove, maybe about 1-2mm on the specific areas where it rubs.  But I think its rubbing only because the cap screw heads are long.  It all boils down to tolerance by the bolt manufacturers.  I wouldn't change your design just yet until someone tries the hex bolts.  For the pistons tho, theres no point in leaving the tolerance so tight.  I would reduce the diameter by 0.5mm .  If someone scaled it down, it would introduce other problems.
comments.author: ericthepoolboy

comments.text: I had m3 hex head bolts in there at first. They were just too big and looked off and I couldn't find any hex bolts smaller than m3. If you know of a source let me know. I'll reduce the piston and do a test fit and see.

comments.text:
where is the alternator, distributor, spark plugs etc? an AC compressor is not of use without all that. also smog air pump, fuel intake system/electrical system and vacuum connections. Revell models and the old Renwal models included all this plus wires so spark plugs (with bulbs in them) lit at proper timing in firing order. and starter was drive motor. Renwal also made a complete drive-line and chassis that functioned with 3 speed transmission for the V8 model. I owned them and built several.
this is almost like the Revell 4 cylinder version still available at hobby shops. very cool 1/4 scale is what most where. nice job indeed just needs a bit more to finish. the Renwal models closed down about 1970 and Revell took up some of their kits but not the largest due to cost exceeding $200. and 2,000 parts plus lots of tiny hardware. I would like to encourage you to continue final details of this type models for educational use and also use some clear parts for observing functions in a class room. tech schools need this also for boat engines etc. as do medical schools for their use like the old human and animal anatomy models of the 2 companys listed above most of which have been abandon years ago. I still own the Visible man and woman models of Renwal for referance, they stand about 15 inches high and Woman has baby parts to show pregnancy.
comments.author: n2ri

comments.text:
The AC compressor is there only because it houses the gear motor and a couple AAA batteries. The accessories are left off because I don't think they add very much to model, educationally or aesthetically. You can explain to someone how and alternator works better than showing them, while trying to explain how the insides of an engine work together is more difficult. There are still more things I want to add to this motor but most of them will just be solid pieces of printed plastic with no moving parts so they'll pretty much be just for looks. And yes, the 22RE uses a timing chain but being able to remove the head and see the valves and pistons was more important than being 100% accurate when creating this model.
I did however, plan on making a distributor that illuminated little LEDs in head at TDC, just like the old models engines that I wanted as a kid. One of the reasons I made this.
comments.author: n2ri

comments.text:
sounds like you really did lots of R&D thinking this through. yes earlier visible engine models also opted for timing gears for best operation. I built both the Renwal V8 and the Revell version which had a better mount for distributor so it didnt wobble off angled gears. as for bearings I smoothed all points of friction so fine that all I had to do is add a bit of mineral oil to the areas and the whole thing could be spun with fingers very easy. thats what must be done for display models like this. and when 3D printed in ABS (which is way better than the Styrene of the 1960s lol) you can acetone vapor parts smooth and shiny. I will PM you me email and we can communicate easier on these subjects. I have 50 years experience that can be tapped for bouncing ideas off of. the revell V8 1st version used a starter motor to turn everything from flywheel and a 'batter' box with wires passing through a switch to turn on motor and spark plug lights. looked like real ones and nobody could tell.
I agree easier design programs and creating good printable files is the next hurdle needing tackled, as the printers are getting near industrial quality now for home use.

remixed_from.title: Timing Belt X GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

remixed_from.author: kungfuroy
remixed_from.title: Parts I used for my Modified Printrbot Simple

description.text:
The area with the blue tape is where I can print. I need some slightly longer rods for the Y-axis to take advantage of the full bed area. The final print area I have is 296mm x 227mm x 180mm. All the parts were printed on the same printer with a 100mm x 180mm x 180mm with build volume upgrade. The only problem I have had with it is that the aluminum either is not flat, or the bed is sagging which makes it hard to level the whole bed, so printing large parts still has some issues. I am also using a heat bed PCB from makerfarm that is taped to the bottom of the aluminum bed using kapton tape. Parts needed:
x12 M3x16 bolts (Red)
x17 M3x20 bolts (Blue)
x2M3x12 (can be a bit smaller) (Green)
GT2 Belts and 20T pulleys
x8 M3 locknuts x8 (can use more if you want)
Build platform
x4 608 skateboard bearings
x2 8mm Linear motion rods 406mm length (can be longer or shorter depending on how big you want your build surface) http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0045DWAAG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 For the build platform I used 12x12in 1/8in thick 6061 aluminum plate which I bought from here:
http://www.speedymetals.com/pc-2406-8360-18-6061-t651-aluminum-plate.aspx
It is sold as a 12x12in plate but mine was 12x12.88in. The original plan was to cut it down to have a 10x10 build platform, but when it arrived, I decided to just use the whole thing. I also used some parts taken from iamjonlawrence's Timing Belt X GT2, Printrbot Simple V2
TensionBlockYGT2.STL
MotorMountXGT2.STL
BearingCap608.STL
Which can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194686 I am also using iamjonlawrence's Printrbot Simple, 300mm Y Axis-No Sag! as my Y axis extension.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242185 Let me know if you have any questions!
Look at the pictures for assembly instructions. If you have any questions let me know.

comments.text: So... this fits rather well into the front of the wooden simple, but on my simple metal, the metal around the base reaches the surface (of the desk/table/whatever it's sitting on) all the way around. I can't mount this quite like you did. I really like the design, so I may just have to tweak that bit so it'll fit on my metal. Looks like I'll be learning solidworks now too!

remixed_from.author: scobo
remixed_from.title: Bed level adjuster for Da Vinci printers (possibly other makes)

title: Modified Da Vinci Printer Bed-level Adjuster

description.text:
I printed the original bed-level adjuster and had issues gluing the
nuts into place. They would break out of the top or the hole would
close while the glue set. I decided to encapsulate the nut so it would become part of the
adjuster. My remix adds more robust tabs at the bottom and a cap on top
to lock in the M3 nut. You will have to keep an eye on the print
and pause it at the right time to insert the nut into the well. Print three to replace all of your adjuster wheels on your print bed. Kudos to scobo for the original design: http://www.thingiverse.com/scobo/about Kudos to Chuck Hellebuyck's excellent video series on Youtube
for the inspiration to make this mod: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZJmkAngpRQg This thing was made with Tinkercad.

You will require three M3 nuts. Print with a .2 layer height and 90% infill. No support is necessary. While printing, watch for the extruder to just reach the top of the well for the nut. Pause the print and insert the M3 nut into the well, make sure it is well seated and flush. I suggest that you position your print near the front of your print
bed for easy access when it comes time to insert the nut into the
top. Look at installing the nut around 85% completion or you can use the original design as a height gauge placed beside your current print,
(once you have the clearance to do so) pausing the print to insert
the nut when your print reaches the top of the original design piece. Restart the print to continue with the cap and you're done!

title: Glass Display Case Slider door standoff

description.text:
I have a display case that I picked up second hand from a store that went out of business when the owner retired.  I use it for my mineral displays.  
The glass doors had been in storage for years.  I guess they never used them at the store.  When I put the doors in, I noticed the glass sliding doors were wobbly at the top and they would bang loudly against the rails and each other.    I guess thats why they avoided using them.  
After lots of research, I found reference to clips for the sliding doors on some website.   That made some sense to have the clips protect the glass and quiet the slide.   I couldn't figure out how to purchase any since I wasn't wholesale so I made my own.    
They work well for me, I hope if you need them you'll find some use from them.  The OBJ file is from tinker cad and you should be able to use that to make any adjustments if you need for glass thickness, etc.

measure your glass thickness and channel thickness, these are currently about 11MM wide for a 7MM glass.    (leaves about 2 mm all around for protection)  
Print them out and clip over the edge of your glass so that it slides into along the tracks easier and without loud banging sides.   
I used the orange PLA because that's what I got right now.

description.text: This is a semi-automated implementation of http://blog.makerbot.com/2010/12/22/calculating-your-feedrate-to-get-awesome-prints/ . It homes the machine, centers the nozzle about 100mm over the build platform, warms up the nozzle and extrudes plastic for a while. There are integrated prompts to explain the process. Due to a bug (or missing feature) in ReplicatorG documented at http://replicatorg.lighthouseapp.com/projects/66325/tickets/11-gcode-m6-pauses-firmware-but-not-replicatorg , the M1 prompts which should help the user along all come out together. Meanwhile the makerbot keeps running, paused at the M6 T0 (tool warmup). Since the M1 pause for the user to time the plastic strings does not work, there is a fixed pause (based on my own experience). This script could be further enhanced to extrude (say for 8 seconds), then stop, wipe (on the integrated ABP wiper) reposition and repeat. However, it's probably best to be measuring steady-state extrusion, so that may be overkill.

Save the script in replicatorg-0023/scripts/calibration/Plastruder calibration.gcode. When you restart ReplicatorG it will show up under File|Scripts|calibration. Click "build" and follow the prompts. See above for discussion of a ReplicatorG bug which makes the prompts confusing.

description.text: I created this case using TinkerCAD (my first 3D thing design). Echenelly's mount is for the uLCD-32PTU display module. This case is for the originally specified uLCD-32PT display module. The mounting hole arrangement is significantly different between the two. A cutout is provided for easy access to the display's uSD Card. I'm currently using this display module along with a modified version of Marlin RC2 running on a Sanguinololu 1.3a. Marco's original design is avaialble here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38749
You will need 4) M3x10mm screws and nuts for mounting the display to the case. For mounting the case to the MendelMax, you can simply reuse the 4) M5x10mm screws from the replaced vertex.

author: mohillbilly

description.text:
Upon purchasing the Plastruder MK5, I was bewildered to discover that there's nowhere to mount the actual control electronics.  (I still have no idea what MakerBot Industries was thinking with this one.)
I rewired and hung the EC off the side of the bot, which is a reasonable configuration with the new relay board.  This is the mount I used.  I didn't post it initially because it's ridiculously simple..but it's so much simpler than the other EC mounts on here that I thought it might be useful to someone!

Look at the picture, it shows these steps.
Print.
Place M3x12 bolts in the outer holes.  The bolts must screw in tightly -- they will become captive, so you can adjust the nuts without being able to access the caps.  You may need to drill the holes out slightly, particularly if you use PLA, but be careful not to widen them too much!  (This is why I slightly undersized them in the SCAD.)
Place one M3x12 or M3x15 in the center hole.  This one can be loose.
Mate the assembly with one M3 nut on the inside of the MakerBot's chassis.
Mount the EC onto the exposed bolts.
Halo Pistol Used in Halo 2
Let me know what you think

Holds shaving soap block and cups the crema whilst lathering up the brush.  
Also renders soap useless for anything else, thus protecting it from the ravening spawn who would misappropriate it.  
The soap I used is from Mermaid Bay, is un-perfumed,  hard and lasts for ever, and made by them (not some cheap industrial soap base gunk). www.mermaidbay.co.nz  
.

This fits a conical frustum shaped block of shaving soap.
Soap is retained underneath by a ring press fitting over bumps. Printed at 0.35mm.
Fully parametric, and customizer compatible. $fn= parameter can be adjusted to improve smoothness. It has been commented out as the customiser doesn't like it.
So for best resolution probably generate STLs at home.
I have been having a problem with openscad crashing during stl export with higher $fn= numbers, hence the blind areas are at lower resolution

description.text:
I am attempting to display a colorized splash of NE Patriots Fandom  
I printed the translucent disc to the size of an outdoor lamp we have. I will attempt to paint the "background" in black and the "Flying Elvis" in Red and Blue. This will be set in front of a lamp to be displayed on our barn.  
Note: the Patriots logo is the actual svg file downloadable from Wikimedia. (Pretty cool) If this is actually able to be displayed, I will also display the text (in a smaller font) citing the source.

123D AutoCAD, sketched a simple circle and added Text. I then found the logo on Wikimedia and was able to download and import the svg file. (all parties will be accredited and is ONLY for personal use) saved, exported as stl. opened makerbot app, added the stl, moved to platform and printed. 1st attempt directly on glass. (unheated, cleaned isopropyl but no hairspray or pva) First layer stuck just fine, second layer constricted and pulled first layer upwards (warped it)  
Printed using PLA as .3mm on 5th gen Makerbot with blue painter tape. Standard temp and speed. No Rafts or Supports.

title: XL-RCP 14.0 HAWX EYE : Nano camera pan-tilt for 808 #16

description.text:
The smallest 3d printed pan-tilt set for FPV: XL-RCP 14.0 HAWX EYE : Nano camera pan-tilt for 808 #16.
I came out an idea to design a pan-tilt camera set small and light enough to be mounted on the nose of a small plane without affecting the CG (Center Gravity) for the use of FPV flight (First Person View). Also most importantly giving me a good full freedom viewing from all angle at close ground proximity flight without being obstructed by cockpit dash view and wings. Originally i had both plane: Drifter Ultralight on FPV using pan only via 808 #16 HD camera keychain with live video output to wireless feed flying via cockpit view to simulate realistic in-cockpit flight experience. However after years of flight its time to convert one of the Drifter Ultralight into "Search and Rescue" style FPV drone like capability which able to fly low altitude and camera able to browse at extremely lower angle to check out ground details and tracking discreet movement below the flight model.
By default it was designed to be placed under the plane nose with high clearance from the ground which elevated by the height of the landing gear. By placing underneath pilot and viewer able to view clean unobstructed scenery unlike traditional cockpit mounted pan-tilt camera set. However this set can be mounted vice versa upwards into the cockpit with slight adjustment to the tilt arm (parts: tilt_arm) and lens module (parts: lens_socket). For more details and instruction check it at this url:
https://www.supermotoxl.com/real-object-design-for-hobby-models/533-xl-rcp-140-hawx-eye-nano-camera-pan-tilt-for-808-16-hd-camera ** Do take note i'm using Z-modeler to build this 3D parts so would look "cracky" on some 3d viewer but no problem during 3D printing.
Editable 3ds file also available at my website for those who wanted to customized/modify the kit meshes.

Bed was painted with ABS glue You should also notify two very important things:
  • DO NOT use fan for ABS!
  • Build a heat chamber (you can use cardbox even) this will improve the quality of your print and also provide good adhesion for the interlayers.

title: This name is under moderation due to a Notice of Claimed Infringement

description.text: I wanted to print an Oscar to test the ColorFabb bronzeFill material I'm reviewing on my website http://nicklievendag.com. I didn't like the ones I found here, so I used a model from a Free Cinema 4D Pack (http://goo.gl/u2ZFjG) as a start. It had too many sharp details, so I remeshed and resculpted it in ZBrush with 3D-printability in mind. I made the bottom base a separate model, so it can be printed in black. I designed it so it can snap onto the statuette, but I ended up glueing them together to create a solid result.

The statuette only needs support under his chin. I manually added supports there in Simplify3D, but if your software can only generate support automatically, you can try to set the threshold to 90 degrees. I printed it at 160 micron, because I was going to sand and polish it anyway. You can read about my polishing process here: http://nicklievendag.com/colorfabb-bronzefill-review/ I printed the statuette with 25% infill and the base with just 5%, because the top surface will be covered anyway. I printed both with 3 perimeter shells.

title: WaterPik WP450 Plug for charging port

description.text: If you use a portable WaterPik, chances are your charging points are corroded with regular wetting and exposure. Since WaterPik doesn't sell plugs (which they very easily can!) here's a 3D printable one that fits the WP450. I cleaned out the two holes with a small jeweller's screwdriver (the irony) otherwise the edges were too fine to print on my Printrbot.

author: Simonwlchan

description.text: Some times I need a joint. This thing is one element of a One Degree of Freedom (1DOF?) joint. Put two of these together back to back, and put an axle through their joined holes, and you have a nice joint. This thing, in conjunction with this other thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6354 make for an "arm" that attaches to a motor, and can be of any length (based on strength of motor and load).

1) Decide how big your rod hole and bearing hole need to be
2) Edit the OpenScad file to the appropriate sizes
3) Print a few of these
4) Press fit radial bearings, whatever you want, into the big round hole.
5) Press fit a rod or tube into the other hole
6) Connect to whatever you're connecting to
7) Rejoice! This makes for an easy way to form 'arm' segments. If one end of a bar is anchored to a servo, and the other end to this thing, then you have the makings of an upper arm, or a leg segment, or whatever. You can use it any place you need a variable angle between two bars.

Follow up to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:599035 Xbox one rear housing backplate, ideal to print in colours for custom controllers. Please note due to the part being more complex than the faceplate, the scan was a little more rough in some areas. Side pods to be uploaded soon, Xbox 360 controller on the way. TIPS ARE WELCOME TO HELP ME SCAN MORE CONTROLLERS!

title: borosilicate glass plate holder for flashforge creator - replicator - clones

description.text:
I needed something to keep the glass I bought from flashforge USA steady on the aluminium bed. After many experiments, I decided to design my own solution. these 4 holders will add pressure on the 4 sides of the plate, keeping it in place during the whole print despite temperature fluctuations. It is also relatively easy to remove the plate and put it back on.  
For glass plate of strictly same size as the aluminium, just take the first file.  
There is also versions adapted for smaller glass than aluminium,   
And a special version made for the PowerSpec 3D, "special raised .25" is the nickname, but we are still improving through successive versions, latest being V5

You'll need some supports for this, don't worry, just let the software place them, there won't be much and they'll be easy to remove. I used ABS, 3 bottom and top plain layers, 2 side layers, 20% infill. To fix it I used longer screws than the original ones. I'll also order other screws just long enough to use the original ending bolts on them, which resists to temperature variations and wont need regular tightening.

title: Spool Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Holds 8 spools of wire

Lasercut the 4 pieces - I used 6mm MDF  
Use 12mm dowels - you need 5.   
2 dowels (for the wire spools) need to be 12mm shorter than the other 3  
Glue each side together - allow to dry.  
Glue the 3 longer dowels into place - make sure the stand isn't twisted.  Allow to dry.  
The 2 shorter dowels should now slot freely into the keyways.  
Enjoy :)

description.text: Sometimes you want to be able to quickly disable a stepper without having to shut down your bot to unplug it. This is especially useful - although by no means limited to - when using a stepper extruder. It's nice to be able to flip a switch and spin your gears by hand. Photos from my DUAL-STEPPER setup ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6362 ); this is connected to allow me to turn off the second stepper and only use one. I built it so I could do some tests and see what difference the second stepper makes. You don't need to be using dual steppers for this to be useful for you, though. Thanks to Kliment (and everyone) on #reprap IRC Freenode for the idea. There's not any files or printed parts required to do this, but just for fun I designed a parametric switch cover to use for the purpose.

Follow along with the pictures.  Whether you have a 2.3 controller (cupcake) or 3.3 controller (Thing-O-Matic) it's the 5th line that you need access to.  You can see here I've got a bizarro 6-pin and 10-pin cable to connect a cupcake controller to a thing-o-matic motherboard.  
Don't worry about all that; no matter which cable you have, the 5th pin is the one to attach the switch to.

If you decide to print and use the attached switch cover:

  • The switch I'm using I found at an Ace Hardware. It's way overkill for this purpose; being intended to conduct actual current. But I liked it's big, solid action. It was about $5. Maybe if you bring in the picture you can find the same one, and use my file just as-is.

  • If not, I hope the parameters in the file will be mostly self-explanatory. Put in the actual dimensions of your switch, and the circumference of the shaft, and that's probably all you need to do. You can mess around with the margins and space for the wires too though, if you prefer it all different.

  • I'd intended the two halves of this to be glued together, but it turns out the locking nuts on the switch shaft hold it together just fine for me.
Similar to Nismo spherical gear knobs with a skirt. This one is 46 mm in diameter, whereas the original is 42 mm.  Has a conical hole at the bottom that M10 screws into.
Print, scew on gearstick, enjoy.

description.text:
Printable Architecture Kit Series 1  
This is a printable Architectural model making kit that is fun to print, build and bring your building designs to life.  
This kit is made up of interlocking modular components that fit seamlessly to each other, making it easy and fun to create endless design configurations.  
This is a fun educational tool for, Students, Architects, Kids, model makers and design enthusiasts.  
Each part was designed to print perfectly without the need for supports or rafts on any FDM FFF 3D Printer.. Just print and build!.  
This series contains Beams, Columns, Floor slabs, Stairs, Roofs, Walls and Interior Partitions in 10 separate STL flies ready to be printed and assembled.   
We will be publishing loads more building parts and interlocking components!  
Download, print and start creating!

During slicing, Set your initial layer thickness to 0. (The first layer printed on the print bed) This allow all parts to fit perfectly. All beams are included in the pack. If you don't have enough you can just print some more.  
Design development done in 3D Studio MAX. Test print done using Ultimaker 2

This is a remix of Wobbly, the ramp walking robot. I cut down on the number of parts by combining the arms with the spacers and making the jetpack part of the body. I also added a peg for the head with a hole in the head so that you can swap the heads out. I also shortened the body a little bit so the legs can move a bit more. I also made some other modifications to the body to make it easier to print when sitting upright. I also made the hole in the legs larger so you shouldn't have to cleanup the pegs to get the legs to move. I think that this would make a great party favor with a bunch of different colored wobbly parts and let the kids make their own Wobbly robot to take home. It can work without a coin if you put the arms down, but I found it works best with a quarter. It will take up to a silver dollar though if you want to try. A couple of videos of them walking:
http://youtu.be/gqPcbVr0dwM
http://youtu.be/2wUMOt1C_0A

You need a body, head, 2 arms, and 2 legs.  Print the body upright.  You need supports under the long pegs for the arms/legs of the body.  That's really the only place you need or want support.  I was able to set supports to 89 degree angle or more to prevent support in the head hole.   Print the head with the eyes facing up, print the arms with the spacer/hole facing up, and the legs with the short side of feet down and hole facing up.  
If the arms or head are too tight, you can sand the pegs lightly.  Do not force the head or arms on if they are too tight or you may break the pegs.  
If you find that the arms or head get too loose from moving them, you can add super glue to the pegs, but don't glue the head or arms on... let the glue dry first.  The glue just makes the diameter of the peg bigger, so that after the glue dries when you put the arms or head back on its a tighter fit.  
Make sure the arms go on far enough so the legs stay close together, but don't let the arms touch the legs so they move freely.

comments.text:
This is the 5th variant you published over the last months - I am starting to believe that you actually printed it ;-)
Does it work stability-wise for you? In my prints, the jars tend to slide out a bit too easily.
One option would be to add a nose at the bottom front of each slot or the structure could be connected at the top/front side as well to make it more stable. Any other ideas?
comments.author: ffs

comments.text:
Yes, its actually taken a lot of trial and error. Measuring the dimensions of the bottles hasn't quite cut it. The first one I got a little overzealous and tried to print a huge spice rack (I have a lot of spices). Well it was a 12 hour print job wasted, because something shifted early in the print and then all the slots were the wrong size. The next time I tried it I decided to go modular so if there was a mistake it would be easier to trash. But, it was a little big as you said. The width of the walls also seemed flimsy so I tried beefing that up. The second to last one I printed was ALMOST perfect, the spices do bend the piece into a significant curvature, but they hold. So this last one will be my last variant I think, at 1/2 a mm wider in diameter. If it doesn't work out I will go back to the second to last one.
What you say makes sense, but since I'm just starting out I don't really know how to do modifications yet, so I'm hoping all these subtle tweaks will get me what I need.

author: NaoUehara

description.text:
Mobius Action Camera 3-Axis Gimbal for STorM32 BGC. Update 4/3/2015
============= Added three new files for use with M3 hardware and 16 x 16 spacing for use with RCTimer GBM2804 motors.
  • Yaw Arm 16x16
    -Roll Arm 16x16
    -Mobius Platform 16x16
    • Original Revision
    =============
    The Mobius Platform used in this design is borrowed from the Mobius Mount found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:346602/#files. It's been heavily redesigned to be more friendly to my printer and to be integrated better into my gimbal design. I also found the pitch center on the platform was too far to the rear. All other components of the design are original. I plan on redesigning the main gimbal frame to hang in the front of the MRC vs underneath (see Thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:666219)and to mount the BGC directly above the yaw motor and to have the anti-vibe bobbins support the gimbal via compression rather than in tension as they support it now. I am still working through fine tuning of the BGC. Initial flights have shown very good performance once the gimbal is balanced and the BGC ACC's are properly calibrated at the flying temperature. I will link to some flight video soon. The Gimbal Top Plate file has been custom designed to fit underneath the front of an HJ 500 Alien quadcopter with slight modifications.

Printed parts at 50% infill with ABS at .2mm layer height. Arms are designed to be printed on their sides to maximize inter-laminar strength. the platform in this design was customized to fit onto my TBS Discovery Clone with some minor modifications. http://www.amazon.com/Neewer-Useful-X-Mode-Multicopter-Quadcopter/dp/B00C593WYU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1421845434&sr=8-1&keywords=alien+x+frame. I used a few safety lanyards to VERY loosely restrain the gimbal frame to the MRC frame in the event that the vibration dampeners come loose. Parts List: -2 2206-140kv hobbyking gimbal motors (Pitch/Roll)
-1 2804-2210 hobbyking gimbal motor (Yaw)

  • 1 STorM32 BGC by Olliw http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2055844&pp=100. I purchased mine from www.readytoflyquads. Other controllers may/may not work, I haven't tried any others.

  • 8 M2 x 8mm long screws for arm-to-motor-rotor attachment
    • -8 M3 x 8mm screws for arm-to-motor-stator attachment. -6 or 8 50g black anti-vibration bobbins from hobbyking. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__40612__Vibration_Damping_Ball_50gram_8_pcs_bag_.html

This is a script to help you diagnose axis problems without making a dozen oddly sloping 20mm cubes. It homes your machine, defining home as X-57 Y-57 which puts X0 Y0 roughly in the center of the build platform. It then makes several moves all at a set speed. The moves include a big "plus" shape, an "X" move into the corners (this one seems particularly prone to bad resonances) and then two trips around the Carabiner V2 shape cut and pasted from rapids created by Skeinforge's "comb" setting (the second copy is rotated 90 degrees). That particular shape is what made me realize my feed speed was too high (and my Y belt was far too tight). After its little dance it re-homes the machine, leaving it positioned so that you can go into "Control Panel" ctrl-J and check the "X Position" and "Y Position" under the Jog controls. I would love to see this done with some big circular moves via G2, but I had trouble with my makerbot following circular moves with uncommanded linear moves that crashed into the side of the machine with no sign of stopping...

Save the script in replicatorg-0023/scripts/calibration/Smooth Axis Test.gcode. When you restart ReplicatorG it will show up under File|Scripts|calibration. Click "build" and watch your machine dance. At the end you will be prompted to open the Control Panel and verify that the machine's X and Y positions are both "-57" (which is what the script set "home" to at startup). If you see some other value then your machine lost steps while dancing. The default speed is F4000 (4000 mm/min, or 66.66 mm/sec to convert to Skeinforge units). This is the same as the maximum speed set in the control panel, though you can set it faster (and lose even more steps). You can test other speeds by adjusting the marked line in the gcode. If you are trying to diagnose a tricky issue you can cut and paste all of the "G1" lines (the vast majority of the script) multiple times to repeat the moves.

title: LOMO Biolam microscope to Sony NEX E-Mount camera

description.text:
Tube to connect the classic LOMO Biolam microscope to modern Sony NEX-style cameras, allowing this microscope to be hooked up to a TV for easier viewing or to be used for photographic or video experiments.  
The length of this tube is entirely arbitrary. I don't know what I'm doing, but it appears to work fine. The magnification of your objective maybe a little off. If anyone could give me some tips on an ideal length, I'd appreciate the comment!  
Finally, it will fit on every fifth generation Makerbot including Replicator Mini, as well as Replicator 2/2X. It is also printable on an Up Mini. Your printer will need a vertical build area of 12cm to print this object.

Designed for and tested in black PLA. Includes supports - peel off the outer ring on the bottom part before use. Plyers or a knife maybe helpful. Loosen the thumbscrew attaching Head/Eyepiece Tube on your LOMO, then place the bottom part of this print in to that area, attach and turn on camera, orient camera however you want and tighten thumbscrew enough to hold in place.  
You may need to change a setting in your camera to allow photos to be taken without a lens, as this passive adaptor does not indicate the presence of a lens to the camera body. On some NEX cameras you may also benefit from changing the HDMI output from Auto to 1080p if you are connecting an external monitor, for higher resolution viewing. Live View tends to be lower resolution, so you might find you get a better image during video recording.
